content.description: Start on a prominent seam in the center of the boulder and climb straight up via crimps to a juggy top out - a good technical line to get your head in the game.
Crouch start on the lowest opposing holds on the right arete - climb straight up. A bit sharp at the start.
content.location: Right Arete of Tasty Pancho boulder.

content.description: Traverse the prominent seam on incut edges to the right arete - climb the arete to bomber jugs at the lip.
content.location: Tasty Pancho boulder, from the Easy Party boulder hike up another 5 minutes amd make a left on a trail that switch backs up the hill, can't miss Tasty Pancho

content.description: Starting on Tasty Pancho avoid the arete and climb straight up the face - finishing on a long move to a good hold on the lip
Cool moves through a series of crimp rails on good stone. Eases in difficulty up high. One of the best problems on the San Francisco Peaks.
content.protection: Pads, landing has been improved with logs.
content.location: From the Easy Party boulder hike up the trail another five minutes, take a left on a side trail that switch backs up the hill. You will come to the Tasty Pancho boulder, Ruby is directly behind up the hill.

content.description: Same start as for Romulan, use a right hand sidepull rail and make a few  tension oriented moves to top out to the right.
content.location: Same start as for Romulan, can be done from a scrunchy sit start if desired.

content.description: Stand start on the left arete, left hand undercling crimp and a good right hand crimp, compression moves around the left side of the arete to a slopey lip encounter. Avoid the rail out right.
content.location: Left arete of the Tasty Pancho boulder.

content.description: Start on an interesting undercling sloper, make moves through awesome pinches, crimp rails and slopers to an exciting OTD finish on jugs!!
content.location: From Tasty Pancho walk directly south through some trees to find the Cougar wall. Quazi mota is on the right

content.description: Stand start on a juggy pocket, move up and left through a series of pockets to a distinct crux on side pulls. Don't blow it past the horizontal seam, where there are a few tricky moves. Continue up the arete on easy terrain to an easy top out... Would recommend trying the moves past the seam on TR.
content.location: From the main trail hike west past Tasty Pancho, continue past Tasty Pancho on the right hand side and you will find the Gem Stone wall.... Approximately 100-200 feet past Tasty Pancho

content.description: Nice arete moves on good holds leads to a technical slab finish on a ramp.
content.location: Furthest right problem on the gemstone wall.

content.description: Start on a jug undercling - manuever up the cobra-like arete using awesome holds. The crux involves a long deadpoint to an incut crimp slot leading to a committing finish high above pads requiring more balance than strength. The top out can get somewhat dirty - would recommend cleaning. This classic feature begs to be climbed.
content.location: From the Easy Party Boulder, continue up the trail another five minutes and take a trail to the left which switchbacks up the hill. Up the trail you will find the Tasty Pancho boulder, walk directly to the left and you will find the ominous Cougar.

content.description: Tasty Pancho was discovered in the Fall of 2008 - development has continued throughout the years and still potential for new problems exist. This area is a mix of freestanding boulders and cliff lines with a few 30+ foot tall highballs. It is recommended to rap the taller problems before trying from the ground as the peaks have a pretty harsh climate and holds can get dirty. Most of the problems are on bulletproof rock, climbing edges and pockets on water streaked stone. There are several warm-ups as well as harder poblems hiding among large aspens and conifers. Rarely will you see anyone here.
